intro: Launaea rogersii, commonly known as the desert dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble dandelions. The plant has a succulent, cushion-like growth form, allowing it to store water and survive in arid environments. Its leaves are typically gray-green, covered in fine hairs that reduce water loss. Launaea rogersii produces small yellow flowers that bloom in spring, followed by fluffy seeds dispersed by the wind.
